awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Molecular layer deposition for polymer cathode fabrication
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a more sustainable electrical energy storage technology. The proposed technology is designed to replace expensive and rare inorganic materials used in lithium-ion battery (LIB) cathodes with low-cost organic polymers.  The proposed technology may offer a domestically sourced, sustainable material solution that enhances charging speed and charge storage capacity of LIBs. This technology may benefit multiple industries by reducing raw materials and manufacturing costs while maintaining battery performance. Reducing the cost and improving the performance of LIBs may impact a range of industries including electric vehicles, consumer electronics, and renewable energy storage. In addition, using domestic feedstocks for LIBs may benefit national security by preventing supply chain disruptions from impacting these sectors.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a molecular layer deposition (MLD) method for synthesizing polymer cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). The proposed technology is focused on displacing traditional transition metal oxide (TMO) cathodes by leveraging MLD to produce polymer-based cathodes with controlled structure and morphology. Results demonstrate controlled growth of high-capacity, fast-charging polymer thin films using MLD. These polymer films exhibit improved charge storage properties over materials formed using traditional polymer synthesis. These beneficial properties are achieved by controlling the thickness, composition, and interchain crosslinking of polymer thin films with molecular-level precision. In addition, the MLD polymer materials nay be easily integrated into existing battery architectures, providing a pathway for market transition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Curators of the University of Missouri

por.por_cntn:
Current lithium-ion battery cathodes rely on expensive and scarce inorganic elements. In recent years, researchers have explored a new concept based on replacing these costly inorganic elements in lithium-ion battery cathodes with abundant and low-cost organic polymer materials. In this project, we studied the commercialization potential of these polymer cathodes. We performed >120 customer discovery interviews, which helped us to develop a deeper understanding of the lithium ion battery market, aided in human resource development of the project team within the lithium ion battery sector, and aided in identifying key parameters for a minimally viable prototype demonstration in this market. Key outcomes included (1) development of a value proposition for the polymer cathodes informed by current market forces, (2) construction of an ecosystem map for polymer cathodes to understand the opportunities for addressing market needs, and (3) identification of a beachhead market for the polymer cathode technology based on urgent pain points in the lithium ion battery markets.

The broader impact/commercial potential of the technology of interest in this I-Corps project is the development of a high power, low cost, and domestically sourced cathode material. Based on input from customer discovery interviews, polymer cathodes are expected to be attractive to multiple industries by reducing raw materials and manufacturing costs and increasing resource accessibility. This technology is expected to be especially attractive to lithium ion battery manufacturers targeting secondary markets of lithium ion batteries other than electric vehicles (EVs), such as consumer electronics, power tools, and medical devices. In addition, using domestic feedstocks for LIBs may benefit national security by preventing supply chain disruptions from impacting these sectors.

 


Last Modified: 02/27/2025
Modified by: Matthias J Young
